history.content:
While EE specialists definitely have a harder time being actively recruited, I don't think it's true that it's more difficult to find jobs. Software has more jobs at the moment, but also more engineers to fill that demand; hardware has fewer jobs but also fewer well-trained engineers. Berkeley EE is among the best in the nation, and companies like Google, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, and IBM have hardware engineer listings all the time.

As for Ph.D.'s in EE... I know for a fact that my EE 40 GSI's research on using ultrasound for fingerprint detection was actively sponsored by Qualcomm, where he'll work after getting his doctorate. From what I hear, industry follows Berkeley research closely and competes for new technologies that come out of the labs.

children.subject: I think that this is extremely presumptive. There is nothing stopping CS and CSE from taking EE classes and many do so.

Take the average software engineer. Ask them to build a low-pass filter and do the correct digital signal processing to complete the control loop on a microprocessor.

Take an EE. Ask them to write a website/backend. They will for sure be able to figure it out.
Someone who finished a 3 month coding bootcamp can be a software engineer. You don't need to spend 4 years at Berkeley to be one.

There are many software engineers who take EE classes (like my CS friend who took classes like EECS 150) and there are many EE who take CS classes. There are EE who do not take CS classes beyond CS61C and there are many CS people who do not take any EE beyond 16a (or b). The point is that it depends on what the person is interested in.

Silly presumptuous statements such as the ones above are ridiculous supposed ego stoking. Is it really necessary to look down on software engineering just because they don't want to do EE? Please study what you want and what is interesting to you! But don't look down on other disciplines just because you didn't specialise in CSE or CS vs EE vs CE ... etc.

smh

I agree with the above anon. Even as a hardcore EE major, I have to give sufficient credit to my CS peers because they are just different specializations. I can do things that amaze my CS peers and sometimes I'm amazed by what they can do. Instead of looking for differences, how about some synergy? After all, we are in EECS.
lel I am a filthy CS major
EEs can do software engineering, but software engineers cannot do EE. Enough said.

I would like to provide my perspective on this important issue as a senior specializing in EE. Given the current market demand/supply of hardware and software talents, I think software definitely is 'hotter' than hardware. If you have been to any career fair held in Berkeley, you will know the validity of my statement. I transferred to EECS because of better job prospect (one of many reasons) but I had a hard time deciding which side to do. At the beginning, I also abhorred coding simply because I didn't have as much experience as other students but in retrospect, those differences in experience can be made up easily. Now getting to your question, I want to emphasize that EE is a labor of love. You cannot do it if you don't love it. You cannot do it if you simply choose it because you don't like coding. (EE involves a lot of coding too!) In terms of marketable skills, you will not easily acquire them from just taking classes. In order to be employable, you need longer years of learning and training and switching specialization even within the field can be hard. So from my perspective, do EE if you absolutely like it and you value your love for hardware more than immediate monetary return. Also be ready for graduate school. (If you hate school and just want to starting working already, then EE may not be your top pick) I understand what you are feeling since I have been on this path before. Let me know if you want to know more.

Here are some responses from our EE faculty: 

Randstat has a nice analysis of the perks of EE jobs; EE was one of their "hot jobs" for 2015.

The numbers are here: https://www.randstadusa.com/workforce360/jobs-the-economy/engineering-jobs-in-demand-for-2015/255/

Salient points:
- geographic supply and demand imbalance: too many EE's in some places and too few in others 
- >10 jobs for every EE graduate
- there appear to be >20,000 job openings across the country for EE's at any given time (I added up the demand circle in the report)

- The national average starting pay for an electrical engineer with three to 10 years’ experience is $90,295. (This figure is national- Berkeley's grads tend to make more)

- EE's have among the highest salary increases year-to-year. An Electronics Engineer had the highest annual increase at >8% 
- these jobs are hard to fill so a Berkeley EE is a goose that lays golden eggs
- Our Ph.d.'s have no trouble finding very high paying jobs.  There are always more internships than students available at Berkeley.

children.subject:
I want to respond, purely as myself (not reflecting anything from the Department's point of view) to OP. In particular, to the line "absolutely abhor coding." If anyone thinks that "EE" jobs don't involve being proficient in writing computer code, they are mistaken. There are a couple of aspects of EECS where you really don't have a choice --- (a) you must be proficient at writing computer code and thinking in a logical fashion; and (b) you must be able to handle mathematical modeling and thinking.  Now, in practice in industry, there are definitely paths where someone might not have to do (b). But honestly, the only paths that I know where someone might be able to avoid writing computer code require getting a PhD (or MBA) and then having people working for you who write the computer code. But then, you probably will have to write some computer code while doing your PhD (or while getting the work experience for the MBA) so there is really no escape.

And culturally as an engineer, you should not *want* to escape something like this. Consequently, if you say you don't like coding and you're a freshman, then it probably just means that you need to get better at it. Once you get good at it, then it may very well be that you don't get a big thrill out of writing code. That's fine. Be sure you choose paths that have aspects that you do find deeply rewarding. (Life is too short to spend working on stuff that doesn't engage you as a person.) Coding isn't the kind of thing that someone can truly abhor. 

Just because our degree requirements let people take course paths which minimize writing code or doing math, it doesn't mean that taking those course paths is necessarily a good idea. You should be talking to your faculty adviser and asking if your plan makes sense from the perspective of building a foundation for a multiple decades long career.

history.content:
Ok, this is probably going to seem like a very stupid question, but what are the job prospects if you specialize in EE? I am a Freshman EECS major, and ever since I came here, I found out that I absolutely abhor coding. However, after taking EE 16A, I have taken a liking to the EE / hardware side... However, some of the stories I have heard about EE specialization kind of scare me... I have heard about some EECS majors "defaulting" to CS specialization because it's hard to find jobs in EE.. I have also heard about some people who have Ph.D's in EE who are having difficulty finding jobs.. It doesn't seem like Berkeley emphasizes EE (as opposed to CS) too much (Though this perception is probably due to my own ignorance)...

How hard is it to get internships in EE? GPA minimum requirements? 

EDIT:

First of all, thank you for all the responses. It is very encouraging to know that so many people are willing to answer my questions.

A clarification to the line "I absolutely abhor coding": This might be a bit of an overstatement. I just am not particularly adept at some of these CS 61B esque style questions, which has in turn caused me to dislike it. I'm not sure if EE is concerned with finding the max distance between 2 nodes in a Binary Search Tree (?). I am perfectly fine with coding that for example, is presented in E7 (i.e. practical applications). I actually enjoy writing the code for the iPython notebooks we have to do in EE 16A. I am perfectly fine with using something like MatLab for mathematical modeling.

Furthermore, my original post heavily implies that I only want to do EE because I don't want to do CS. I have many interests in EE that I want to explore (i.e. fiber optics, solid state), and overall prefer the designing and integration of multiple concepts that EE requires. I believe that if I had been exposed to EE before taking a CS class, I would have still wanted to do it. I think having to come up with a design for a circuit given a specified problem (and actually getting it right) is extremely satisfying.
